Posts.Content: Jan 11, 2009 10:24PM carlag67 wrote: Jancie, It sounds like you have the right attitude.  I was dx in Feb 08 IDC 2.8CM Grade 3 Est+ Her2+.  It is very overwhelming and even a nurse would be overwhelmed with all of the things that you have to learn.  Take someone with you to your appointments so you have a second set of ears to listen to the answers.  I asked a lot of questions but did not always remember the answers.  So much is thrown at you at once.  Yeah they give you books and books and books....   It is perfectly normal to feel anxiety and worrisome.  I too had to get a script for xanax.  I could not sleep at night.  Especially about two weeks after my bilateral mast.  What I feared the most was the chemo.  I literally would rather die than to go through that.  I cried day and night for two weeks.  Until one day my aunt told me to get up off my rear and think about my kids and that I was stronger than that.  I guess that is what I needed. LOL  Someone to just to give me the little push that I needed.  From then on my attitide changed.  That is the key to getting through.  POSITIVE ATTITUDE!!!!   I am sorry that you have to go through this!  But that that does not kill us makes us stronger!  You will make it through this!  Chemo is not as bad as it has been in the past.  I had 16 rounds of chemo and have to have Herceptin(hormonal therapy) for a year.  Then follow with 5 years of tamoxifen due to the fact that mine was estrogen positive and HER2 positive.  No journey is the same but you are in the right place for support. Hugs & Blessings to you!!
